reasoning: The critique targets a key step in §2.4.1: that moral realism makes the true morality likely “alien/distant” and thus less motivational, supporting pessimism about WAM-convergence even under good conditions. This matters to the essay’s anti-WAM case, but it’s only one pillar (the essay also argues antirealism yields divergence, plus separate motivational/blocker considerations), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The objection is fairly strong: realism alone doesn’t imply a prior over moral truths skewed toward “weirdness,” and many realist views (reasons/agency-based, some constructivist-leaning realisms, etc.) could predict substantial overlap with human concerns, so the essay plausibly needs extra argument to justify the “alienness” likelihood claim. Still, it doesn’t fully overturn the essay’s broader skepticism, since motivation and convergence could fail for other reasons even on realism. The critique is mostly correct, clearly stated, tightly focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Moral realism doesn’t imply alien, non-motivating moral truths without further argument
